Award.AwardTitle: Conference: The 10th Q-Bio Conference, July 27-30, Nashville, TN

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Q-Bio (Quantitative Biology) Conference brings together a community of researchers interested in developing a theory-driven and predictive understanding of biology. Such an understanding provides not only insight into basic biological phenomena, but is also a foundation for advances in biotechnology, agriculture and medicine. The conference will bring together researchers working in biology, mathematics, physics, chemistry, computer science and engineering, and broaden participation in this emerging area by supporting the attendance of early career researchers, women and members of groups under-represented in the field. Through encouragement and support of the attendance of junior researchers (including postdoctoral fellows and graduate students) the conference will provide opportunities for them to meet with senior, leading investigators to exchange ideas and information, thereby helping to train the next generation of researchers in the field.

The Conference will include keynote talks, oral presentations and opportunities for poster presentations; these will all be organized around a common set of themes. These themes will be: Cellular processes and signaling networks in prokaryotes and eukaryotes; Ecology and evolution of cellular collectives; Mechanisms of force sensing, transmission and generation and their relationship to signaling processes; Stochasticity in cellular signaling; Computational methods in the study of systems-level cellular processes; Metabolic processes and cellular signaling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From July 27 through July 30, 2016, Vanderbilt University in Nashville, TN, hosted the 10th q-bio Conference with ~200 attendees. The q-bio conference engages a broad scientific community that employs quantitative approaches to understand, model and control biological processes. The 10th q-bio Conference emphasized training new researchers, collaboration across fields, and the dissemination of novel experimental and theoretical tools. Prior to the official opening of the meeting, we hosted a graduate and undergraduate symposium for students attending the q-bio summer schools. The  banquet talks were pitched to trainees and highlighted successful approaches for discovery and unsolved research problems. The opening tutorials and workshops were aimed to introduce cutting-edge modeling tools and experimental techniques to graduate-level trainees and junior researchers. Trainees had multiple opportunities to discuss their work through the poster spotlight talks, heavily attended poster sessions, and the pre-meeting symposium.

Researchers from the USA were involved throughout all aspects of the scientific program. Out of 20 confirmed speakers, 13 were from the USA. As in previous years, the meeting comprised about 200 attendees, and about 80% of the speakers and participants were from the USA. This NSF award, provided support for: 1) travel funding for nine early-career US researchers (i.e. postdoctoral or early-stage assistant professors), who attended the program as workshop, meeting, or tutorial speakers and participants; and 2) funding for full or partial registration and housing wavers for thirteen junior US participants (graduate and undergraduate students) to attend workshops and tutorials, and participate in the general program. The proposal enabled us to increase visibility of women and minorities working in quantitative biology as well as help advance the careers of young investigators.
